nodes.bodyText: This is a pretty neat trick. Do we have any business-logic-related thing we can verify here other than there are no threads and the worker is null?

It's the last assertion line:
    assertNull(worker.activityWorker);

Right - I meant is there something besides that we can assert, like something doesn't happen that otherwise would? Perhaps an integ test that verifies the worker doesn't attempt to perform any activities?
If you think it's low value don't bother. I was just curious if there's something we could do here besides "this is null"
Another option is to schedule a local activity and after it completes schedule a normal activity and let it timeout with ScheduleToStart to show that no activity worker is present.
Added two tests for local and normal activities.
I would change all this check to activityWorker != null which would make it more obvious.
I wanted to use this option explicitly in order to be able to catch potential bugs more easily in case if activityWorker is null when it shouldn't be.

To have workflow tasks only don't call worker.registerActivity. The reason to have this option is to support only local activities by this activity worker.
Should we rename it to something more explicit? More like setLocalActivityWorkerOnly?
I don't have strong opinion about naming here as long as default false means normal worker, let me rename to localActivityWorkerOnly if you like it better.
Would you add a comment that explains what is the meaning of this flag?
